title: Secondary – Cycle 1 – Progression of Learning - Geography (2010)
subject: Social Sciences

document.title: Secondary – Cycle 1 – Progression of Learning - Geography (2010)

FC364ABA10014736BD85E46567848EE3.description: Indicates criteria established by UNESCO to include natural parks on the World Heritage List (e.g. the park must be an outstanding example of the Earth’s history or of biological processes)

4C13D8AC59E84741927FA1E04D6E0916.description: Indicates human actions that may threaten a protected park (e.g. road construction, exploitation of natural resources, poaching)

B933AF501F1145668F2B46A6CC07D2EE.description: Indicates natural hazards that may threaten a protected park (e.g. forest fires, erosion, flooding)

C87B722BE8D240FBAAFE56FCEAE13E01.description: Explains some of the impacts associated with visiting the natural park studied (e.g. in the Saguenay ? St. Lawrence Marine Park, visitors who do not follow the regulations may disturb the balance of the flora and fauna)

AAED881694FC4623B3D78A336302507A.description: Explains why protecting the natural environment must be reconciled with recreational activities in natural parks (e.g. the ecosystems protected by natural parks are fragile and recreational activities of visitors must be controlled to avoid disrupting these environments)

D16DB8D4BC904DF6911F522B3E0E97BA.description: Issue affecting a natural park or parks

0D9E51C5038947B3A5F457956764563B.description: Indicates some of the infrastructure in place in the natural park studied (e.g. reception centres, marked trails and wharfs at the Parc national de l’Île-Bonaventure-et-du-Rocher-Percé)

5725CF8E4C614ACEA6B8C049D670C7F5.description: Indicates measures taken to protect the natural park studied (e.g. restricted access to certain areas, use of marked trails, restricted number of visitors at Mingan Archipelago National Park Reserve)

36ECB9907A454336AEF5613E66C962F9.description: Names different zones of the natural park studied (e.g. conservation zones, wildlife and natural land zones, recreational activity zones at the Galapagos National Park and Marine Reserve)

BC805613644D42AD8E8E238C0A6A7CAE.description: Planning and development of a natural park

DD8FED3E980C4C289EA3C2A013EDDB91.description: Explains the economic benefits for the region surrounding the natural park studied (e.g. opening Banff National Park to the public creates a demand for workers, who in turn create a demand for services, which generates new jobs)

89AD76F95A76452AB51C3EC1140A3037.description: Indicates rules to follow to protect the natural park studied (e.g. respecting marked trails, flora, restricted areas in Banff National Park)

EC265411A15145D8B339E54F8FC11A03.description: Lists recreational activities authorized in the natural park studied (e.g. hiking, ecotourism, animal watching in Forillon National Park)

44DD98900E8742888B6E4EA225E9EEDB.description: Indicates why the natural park studied has been created (e.g. to protect endangered species in the Galapagos National Park and Marine Reserve; to protect natural phenomena such as glaciers in Banff National Park; to protect nesting sites in the Parc national de l’Île-Bonaventure-et-duRocher-Percé)

9570EE88301648BC879D061333CE0773.description: Lists natural heritage elements in the park studied (e.g. fauna, flora, wetlands, glaciers in Banff National Park)

5302489EE63340EE8EAEA67B77492A1B.description: Locates protected natural parks on a map of the world (e.g. Forillon and Banff national parks in Canada; the Galapagos National Park and Marine Reserve in Ecuador; the whale sanctuary of El Vizcaino in Mexico; Sagarmatha National Park in Nepal; Serengeti National Park in Tanzania; the Giant’s Causeway in Ireland; Yellowstone National Park in the United States)

CD02BB51C3A948AA826E6DB1014FFA4D.description: Locates the natural park studied in the appropriate continent and country

D199B3ED82BA436494F2EF9BE94D536D.description: Names organizations that address the claims of Native peoples (e.g. national governments, the United Nations)

5BD6177654C94B638D20209BC3AC125B.description: Names claims of Native peoples who have still not concluded government agreements (e.g. land, economic, cultural claims)

030B88035B7D43D5B2A714F829B4A6E6.description: Explains some of the repercussions of measures taken to protect Native territories studied (e.g. since signing the James Bay and Northern Québec Agreement in 1975, the Cree have had decisional power over their territory, particularly in matters associated with resources and protection of their way of life)

184B2CBA14404F0590C437D3287665E0.description: Indicates human actions that have affected the Native territory studied (e.g. creation of retention lakes have disrupted the environment, flora and fauna among the Cree)

66358E2FC01B4E2EBEFFD8E9B8FC720C.description: Names partners with whom Native peoples share their territory (e.g. federal or provincial governments, resource companies)

81930282D16148B88667CB70BE8D4401.description: Issue affecting a Native territory or territories

8E4BDCB35CC549C2AA8254E24AC8AFDA.description: Indicates development constraints associated with nordicity in the Native territory studied (e.g. permafrost makes it difficult to build aqueduct and sewer systems in Nunavut)

D65753FAECCC4F40A5A7C53A31E83860.description: Indicates infrastructure put in place by Native peoples in the territory studied (e.g. creation of recreational and tourist facilities and sites among the Cree)

4855A724E1E7404AB0F981032655BD70.description: Indicates transportation infrastructure in the Native territory studied (e.g. rail system among the Naskapi; ports and airports in Nunavut)

729D831A39134189BA93665E7875DDF8.description: Lists characteristics of how the Native territory studied is organized (e.g. wide dispersal of villages and airport installations in Nunavut)

9E5E11C6FF404754B45B5CA1A15EC942.description: Planning and development of a Native territory

F98E4F2D69BE44D4BB59AC536CC432BE.description: Names activities associated with modern life in the Native territory studied (e.g. hydroelectric, logging and mining sites; tourism and transportation among the Cree)

598A9A7369934D158FB66E2D7803898C.description: Lists activities associated with traditional life in the Native territory studied (e.g. hunting, fishing, trapping in Nunavut)

C17424DAC2454EB9B9AA63D630963856.description: Names different institutions that regulate the Native territory studied (e.g. band council, chief, councillors among the Naskapi)

F30CEA025E084330A839CACA2C5759E4.description: Names the agreements signed between Native peoples and the government of Québec: Northeastern Québec Agreement (for the Naskapi); James Bay and Northern Québec Agreement (for the Cree)

E8DA112B9E5447B9979F4EBB56AAC003.description: Names recognized ancestral rights of the Native people in the territory studied (e.g. Crees’ right to hunt, fish and exploit resources)

26F32407EDAF47C19F1253242F19496B.description: Names elements of the culture of the Native people inhabiting the territory studied (e.g. Inuktitut language, inukshuk, parka in Nunavut)

A9969992CA794A7BAC90DB8BA43D562A.description: Indicates criteria used by the United Nations for the recognition of Native peoples (e.g. they must be existing descendants of peoples who inhabited a territory long before it was colonized)

3686D67CF4D046ACA4C6A2179C053F38.description: Locates Native territories on a map of the world (e.g. Aboriginal territory in Australia; Cree, Naskapi and Inuit territories in Canada; Chiapas in Mexico)

167679AF4FCD4E4587905108E1F6AE79.description: Locates the Native territory studied in the appropriate continent and country

8B495575BAF8443D8E529816A285D3DB.description: Indicates solutions adopted to reduce environmental problems associated with farming practices (e.g. regulations to protect agricultural territories; decreased use of pesticides and fertilizers)

DE01AFA092DD43948873C2112494C367.description: Names environmental problems associated with farming practices in territories subject to natural hazards (e.g. fertilizers and pesticides can pollute waterways; monoculture can deplete the soil of nutrients and contribute to its degradation)

390956F37C514D798BCD4D2DDE762CBC.description: Indicates measures taken to reduce problems associated with water management in the agricultural territory studied (e.g. in Bangladesh, dikes are built to prevent floods)

F65F75BE11BB43A2BE1194575D7AA817.description: Lists problems associated with water management in the agricultural territory studied (e.g. erosion caused by poor irrigation techniques in the Canadian prairies; falling water tables caused by excessive water use in the Sahel)

6F6E06B94BDD48CB9B71E43C1E5DF7F2.description: Explains the relationship between human actions and the creation of an artificial risk in the agricultural territory studied (e.g. in the Canadian prairies, pesticides and fertilizers can pollute waterways; in the Sahel, digging wells for herds combined with overgrazing can deplete groundwater resources; in Bangladesh, cutting mangroves has destabilized the shorelines of the territory, making river banks more vulnerable to cyclones)

DE84772D0C2B4491812C70F696418F9F.description: Explains how human actions can intensify a natural risk in the agricultural territory studied (e.g. deforestation accelerates erosion during floods; monoculture, i.e. the repeated planting of one crop in the same area, destabilizes soils)

4FBA58DCA89F46F6B94B6EE888739586.description: Issues affecting an agricultural territory or territories subject to natural hazards

881FE0C0E9F1405C9DCC895FBB4CC1CC.description: Indicates methods used to protect the agricultural territory studied from a natural hazard (e.g. in Bangladesh, dikes and dams help control flood levels; in the Canadian prairies, planting trees, irrigation and new technologies help mitigate the effects of drought)

9BBE34A6D0584BB78B857D29D1D66ED7.description: Explains how certain practices can increase natural hazards in the agricultural territory studied (e.g. in Bangladesh, cutting mangrove trees to create shrimp basins increases the risk of flooding; in the Sahel, frequent seasonal movements of livestock to grazing lands intensify the desertification of the territory)

E2DEC58F054F46CD92DF671C08C40FDD.description: Indicates the role of transportation networks in the agricultural territory studied (e.g. in the Canadian prairies, trucks transport products to trains, which are used to ship exports)

18F2D7D732B74B4CB937CEF05AFF8E39.description: In Indicates types of farming installations in the territory studied (e.g. in Bangladesh, stilt houses surrounded by dikes minimize flood damage; in the Canadian prairies, wells and reservoirs for livestock are installed in case of droughts)

7B769939C64B491F96741E85CB094DCB.description: Planning and development of an agricultural territory subject to natural hazards

0224476B49D149E0A7F552C10CBB7185.description: Indicates how a natural hazard can turn into a natural disaster in the agricultural territory studied (e.g. in Bangladesh, farmers looking for fertile land settle in the Ganges delta despite risks from floods and cyclones that regularly cause heavy material and human losses)

77DEBAFF628649A2917370ACC38522CC.description: Indicates farming or breeding practices in the agricultural territory studied (e.g. intensive rice cultivation with several harvests per year in Bangladesh; movement of livestock in search of grazing land and water in the northern part of the Sahel)

77050AA152C14FACBA248F6F287A5902.description: Explains consequences of certain natural phenomena for the agricultural territory studied (e.g. in Bangladesh, floods during monsoon season erode farm land and destroy crops)

86E736BCF61045B0B270C1416B6ABB59.description: Lists the natural phenomenon or phenomena to which the agricultural territory studied is subject (e.g. floods, cyclones and tsunamis in Bangladesh; desertification in the Sahel; drought in the Canadian prairies)

2521E504EAF2447AB7E84B9E9FF84BC9.description: Explains the relationship between the latitudinal position of the agricultural territory studied and elements of its climate (e.g. the Sahel’s aridity is due to its location in sub-Saharan Africa; the heavy rains in Bangladesh are due to its location in the tropics)

1F7ABE65323249D89E7E9DDCC4CC73D0.description: Characteristics of an agricultural territory subject to natural hazards

44AFB770EC1749CAB70EFD30A21619CC.description: Locates, on a map of the world, agricultural territories subject to natural hazards (e.g. Northeast India; the Sahel; the Canadian prairies; areas around the Mediterranean; Bangladesh; the Mekong Basin)

71525F2187014350AA4D6D9EF3A95644.description: Locates the agricultural territory studied in the appropriate continent and country

BCE82E0712FE4FA8AF4E7FD27F71A3E4.description: Location of an agricultural territory subject to natural hazards

8489B8203A8543FAA9EDD9CD2057A59D.description: Knowledge related to Agricultural Territory Subject to Natural Hazards

13C01108E4224A2EBF96DEDAC6189731.description: Explains how certain agricultural practices affect the global food equilibrium (e.g. the use of corn and wheat in biofuel production has caused food crises and raised the price of flour worldwide)

5C9B544071DA4A29AE05CBF28A87783A.description: Indicates solutions to problems affecting farmers in the territory studied (e.g. to compensate for the shortage of agricultural workers in Québec, employment programs have been established to allow farmers to hire seasonal workers from Mexico)

DF7DF58EC4FC4148BD945481AF8003A5.description: Indicates measures taken to limit the environmental impact of farming practices (e.g. passing laws to regulate farming practices; defining riparian strips; reforesting shorelines)

89B2B93EE41543A0ABE36B96E531DE92.description: Names laws adopted to protect farming and restrict the development of non-agricultural activities in rural areas in the territory studied (e.g. Act respecting the Preservation of agricultural land and agricultural activities in Québec; Farm Land Protection Policy Act in California)

7C702D4106514C5993E82334D30D3D11.description: Indicates infrastructure in place in agricultural areas of the territory studied (e.g. highway extension, industrial warehouses, sports centres and urban sprawl in California)

4487368D53984AE7BA91E882F545F5DD.description: Explains consequences of certain farming practices for the environment (e.g. intensive fruit tree cultivation requires the use of strong fertilizers, which contributes to soil nutrient depletion; annual irrigation of vegetable crops requires large amounts of water, which reduces groundwater levels)

EDB281BC0EDC4089B96D17DAC59C738F.description: Issues affecting an agricultural territory or territories in a national space

8631C7662A6F479DA3F6770C0B0D72CD.description: Indicates infrastructure used to increase the productivity of the agricultural territory studied (e.g. irrigation canals in California; dams to control water levels in rice paddies in Japan)

CEFAFEF278DF43ABA8F8BA55024CD9C5.description: Establishes a connection between certain characteristics of the climate and the infrastructure of the agricultural territory studied (e.g. the desert climate of central California makes it necessary to construct dams and develop irrigation systems; Québec’s harsh winter conditions make it necessary to build greenhouses to ensure year-round supply of certain vegetables)

644FD318447F492396EDE90A39F171EC.description: Names the main type of farming practices used in the agricultural territory studied (e.g. intensive farming practices used on small farms in Japan)

3FE270B8FACA4A79960589060A87254B.description: Planning and development of an agricultural territory in a national space

BB0028330AEB4B35A5B4DA9810C89C1C.description: Identifies problems that affect farmers in the territory studied (e.g. finding workers, attracting potential successors, obtaining a fair price for agricultural products in Québec)

816D466279304E87BEAE093FAA4DC6A5.description: Establishes the proportion of the labour force employed in agriculture in the territory studied (e.g. in 2009, 5% of the population in Japan; 2% of the population in California)

569FD2F564C94726AB93C67898F1A439.description: Lists the main agricultural products (crops) of the territory studied (e.g. rice, potatoes, fruit in Japan; vegetables, fruit, nuts, cotton, vines in California)

678BBE2007DD485988C53DCC62047DE0.description: Indicates the natural factors that influence the location of the agricultural territory studied (e.g. soil fertility, length of growing season, precipitation regime, latitude and altitude in Québec)

5496EB92D5EB4A879599D0D517522CC9.description: Establishes the relative size of the territory devoted to agriculture in the territory studied (e.g. in 2005, the agricultural territory of Québec accounted for 2% of the national territory and that of Japan, for approximately 13% of the national territory)

A8AA7A675014432E9BAD18147F5EC071.description: Explains the location of the main agricultural areas in the territory studied (e.g. in Japan, the agricultural territory of each island is located mainly on narrow coastal plains and along mountainsides because of the country’s hilly topography)

5BE1323BAA5D4DE6850ABCA30CA06540.description: Characteristics of an agricultural territory in a national space

BBEF2DABDF5F4FEAB4FA0253CF83AE30.description: Locates the main agricultural territories on a map of the world (e.g. the Great Plains of North America, the Pampas of Argentina, the Great Russian Plain, the basins of Western Europe, Southeast Asia, Western Australia)

3C6EBCF9EEAA4418BFBCAAD4A5798BA1.description: Locates the main agricultural territories on a map of the world (e.g. the Great Plains of North America, the Pampas of Argentina, the Great Russian Plain, the basins of Western Europe, Southeast Asia, Western Australia)

8188DCFD50B04ADAAABC38DCF46DD6FD.description: Locates the agricultural territory studied in the appropriate continent and country

E3DCE1D950924A3F89AFC3853E5C3672.description: Knowledge related to  an Agricultural Territory in a National Space

AFD753DD714C4C0F86F1D148DBB68DE2.description: Indicates measures taken to attenuate the effects of declining industrial activity in the region studied (e.g. development of resource processing activities and industry diversification in the Saguenay ? Lac-Saint-Jean region)

E9742D1778554CFB87004385BAFBC5C0.description: Explains some of the repercussions of relocating industries in developing countries (e.g. job creation and the development of road infrastructure and energy distribution networks improve living conditions; less stringent environmental standards increase air and water pollution)

82562B7F95D840B9B0B8C8D9D48A4974.description: Explains some consequences of declining industrial activity for industrial regions (e.g. plant closures cause direct and indirect job losses, which increase unemployment and reduce the standard of living of the population in the region)

9D0CC1766D724590AD35970C0F7D536F.description: Indicates causes of declining industrial activity in industrial regions (e.g. relocation of industries to developing countries; resource depletion)

B43803FBD5DB4983A123500AF027151A.description: Indicates reasons for relocating a business (e.g. cheaper labour costs, less stringent environmental laws)

92BB66F7293E4036A95164943EE6E1F8.description: Indicates measures taken by businesses to reduce industrial pollution in the region studied (e.g. setting up water treatment plants in the Montérégie region to purify waste materials discharged into the St. Lawrence River)

BBF85E921D284DEC9824A12A40F6E60B.description: Explains how the presence of industry in the region studied affects the environment (e.g. pollutants emitted into the air and water disrupt the ecological balance of the Saguenay ? Lac-Saint-Jean region; burial of hazardous wastes contaminates the soil and affects the health of residents in the American and Canadian Great Lakes region)

64A8A280F17843B8ACB6988B9ACC7CE2.description: Issue affecting an industrial region or regions

36057451C5DA49C5AC5EB3DABA3DB313.description: Indicates negative effects of industry in the region studied (e.g. acid rain caused by steel mill emissions in the American and Canadian Great Lakes region)

63542758EBAF4562B3267933FAC0C1E8.description: Indicates constraints faced by businesses in the industrial region studied (e.g. having to comply with urban planning laws and locate a plant in an industrial area in Estrie)

D3D537B7D3E14DDEBAA20672A77D79F4.description: Explains the relationship between the industrial sites of the region studied and access to supply and distribution networks (e.g. industrial sites in the American and Canadian Great Lakes region are located next to the St. Lawrence Seaway, ports, rail lines and highways that facilitate access to raw materials and the distribution of finished products)

AC87A943D3144E52BAB6088B0D85CEB9.description: Indicates the specialized infrastructure used to develop the industrial region studied (e.g. aqueduct system, energy distribution networks, specialized waste collection services in the American and Canadian Great Lakes region)

52C665572EA3446DAB304D9D264B105B.description: Planning and development of an industrial region

EC8170DA3F0A4109AAA4A94DB8717552.description: Indicates factors that promote the concentration of industries in the industrial region studied (e.g. proximity to agri-food markets in Montérégie; concentrated population and large pool of consumers in the American and Canadian Great Lakes region)

F618C27128E546AD92D91DE30307EE31.description: Explains why a particular location promotes the development of industry in the region studied (e.g. the proximity to energy sources in the Saguenay ? Lac-Saint-Jean region makes aluminum less costly to produce; the concentration of skilled labour in the Québec City region promotes the development of the pharmaceutical industry)

FBE8F61964494EAC95D0CC16986D1459.description: Indicates measures that have contributed to the development of the industrial region studied (e.g. government subsidies to businesses in the Montréal region)

AA2317B796E640E3B4548B9FBF59DA84.description: Indicates natural factors that have contributed to the development of the industrial region studied (e.g. proximity to Lakes Superior, Michigan, Huron, Erie and Ontario and the St. Lawrence River for the American and Canadian Great Lakes region; presence of mineral deposits in AbitibiTémiscamingue; abundant energy resources in Saguenay ? Lac-Saint-Jean)

39FD2FD8C21B4D189DDA7E57BBBD7B95.description: Names the main industrial clusters of the region studied (e.g. Pittsburgh, Detroit, Kingston in the American and Canadian Great Lakes region)

294FFCB8336546F6AB423C93BAE41A85.description: Lists types industries found in the industrial region studied (e.g. aluminum smelters in Saguenay ? Lac-Saint-Jean, steel mills and vehicle assembly plants in the American and Canadian Great Lakes region)

8BEBE448F3AF40DC8560085AB8B903C6.description: Locates major industrial regions on a map of the world (e.g. American and Canadian Great Lakes region, southern Hokkaido in Japan, southeastern United Kingdom, São Paulo region in Brazil, Alexandria in Egypt)

F921AB9995BD44C59119EE508F73ABC7.description: Locates the industrial region studied in the appropriate continent and country

7A5B1DFE770F4E9E826EB7DAE7F6C197.description: Indicates some of the most energy-intensive industries (e.g. aluminum, steel, petrochemical plants)

775D803897A24A3AA762B078844F485A.description: Explains the impact of growing energy consumption on the environment (e.g. growing energy consumption worldwide contributes to global warming and environmental degradation)

8B8ABD0EF64A488B931CD037ECD8826D.description: Explains the impact of the development of alternative energy sources (e.g. biofuel production requires large quantities of grain and thus contributes to the world’s food crisis)

BCF494118B82465CB9F60F4DECFB602F.description: Indicates the consequences of energy resource development for the region studied (e.g. flooding of vast areas of land in Jamésie; degradation of the environment and depletion of groundwater caused by tar sands oil extraction in Alberta)

E546DD61FDB946F2BE148CC9FA9D7A08.description: Indicates measures taken to help reduce energy consumption and increase self-reliance (e.g. dual energy, hybrid vehicles, improved public transit, development of energy-efficient appliances)

77E28DA6BFFB4B6B87BED56FCD9290E0.description: Indicates measures taken to improve energy supply and reduce energy dependence in the region studied (e.g. search for renewable resources in Jamésie; creation of OPEC in the Persian Gulf)

B50C3BC998B94790BA14D64C95CAA6E3.description: Issue affecting an energy-producing region or regions

DC5F267436424B4E8955AE7072F35B33.description: Indicates means used to transport energy resources in the region studied (e.g. high-voltage power lines connect hydroelectric dams to power stations and transmission and distribution substations in Québec; oil and gas pipelines transport hydrocarbons from extraction sites to refineries in Alberta)

19014C3DB8434D3E9F1B38551889D5D4.description: Names organizations associated with the development of the energy source exploited in the region studied (e.g. Hydro-Québec for hydroelectric power in Jamésie and the Côte-Nord; multinationals for oil production in the Persian Gulf; Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries [OPEC] for oil production in the Persian Gulf)

DD9D6CF9E26844D38D2FF04EBB6D8A6F.description: Indicates infrastructure used to process energy resources in the region studied (e.g. oil refinery in Alberta; hydroelectric power plants, wind farms in Québec)

8B38769052A24365A96CE4572CBFA536.description: Indicates infrastructure used to exploit the energy source in the region studied (e.g. derricks are used to extract oil in the Persian Gulf; open pit mines, to extract oil from tar sands in Alberta; oil rigs, to drill oil in the Persian Gulf; reservoirs and dams, to generate hydroelectric power in Jamésie)

D8F91A149CA94858B6958B053B9FBE81.description: Planning and development of an energy-producing region

7BF6057FA2764A3F83FC32BCB17BCD9C.description: Indicates energy sources developed in the region studied (e.g. hydroelectric energy produced in the Côte-Nord region is a renewable energy source; hydrocarbons extracted in Alberta are a nonrenewable energy source; wind energy in Jamésie is an inexhaustible energy source)

8224F46BE9EB438188E775D04472FDBB.description: Explains the relationship between certain characteristics of the natural environment and the form of energy developed in the region studied (e.g. the steep slope and strong flow of the La Grande River and the Great Whale River in Jamésie are conducive to the production of hydroelectric power; the accumulation of decayed plant and animal life on ancient seafloors helped create oil and natural gas deposits in Alberta and around the Persian Gulf)

00119F0E1AC5414297003C31B9F3D98F.description: Indicates uses for the form of energy developed in the region studied (e.g. in Alberta, hydrocarbons are used as a source of fuel for vehicles, heating and power plants)

1DF474F5758A49ECB382BB596556C2AE.description: Names the form of energy developed in the energy-producing region studied (e.g. hydroelectric power in Jamésie; oil and natural gas in the Persian Gulf)

407F0E8206BF4ED59CE87C31812BF879.description: Locates, on a world map, the countries that consume the most energy per capita (e.g. in 2010: Australia, Canada, United States, Finland, Norway, New Zealand, Sweden)

41974098C89B4E8698897E447C73A3A8.description: Locates oil - and gas-producing countries on a map of the world (e.g. Saudi Arabia, Brazil, Canada, China, United Arab Emirates, Iraq, Iran, Kuwait, Nigeria, Russia, Venezuela)

CFB2E68EDCC44FD1AFC28E19773EBBF2.description: Locates the energy-producing region studied in the appropriate continent and country

33B2C0D6E6714BE3B9341A3CD2749B51.description: Indicates means used to reconcile the interests of different stakeholders in the forest region studied (e.g. private forest landowners in British Columbia grant access rights to recreational tourist organizations; the Brazilian government sets aside reserves in the Amazon forest for the exclusive use of the Native population)

970052C359B64FD0ACB2F92676B05C14.description: Indicates practices that help renew forest resources (e.g. reforestation using fast-growing tree species; thinning; selective cutting)

1E94DEBAE60343E2AD3E7D953D1BBF56.description: Explains consequences of excessive logging for the environment (e.g. once trees are cut down, surface runoff increases, leading to soil erosion and soil nutrient depletion)

D7BBB8DB639C42909DD9685D45084FF6.description: Indicates practices that contribute to the depletion of forest resources in the region studied (e.g. excessive logging in Abitibi-Témiscamingue; development of agricultural land to the detriment of forests in the Amazon)

19E1205C8C2749E88A263DD26796A66E.description: Lists threats to forests in various regions of the world (e.g. tree diseases, pests, forest fires)

4BD39B78EE954D38B8EB8822291C469F.description: Issue affecting a forest region or regions

F6BDDBEA232C4F9F833915C70DD62C8C.description: Indicates the infrastructure in place in the forest region studied (e.g. logging roads to access logging sites in the Charlevoix region; construction of check stations, lodging facilities and docks in an outfitting operation in the Mauricie)

016B4C06399B4B08A7B7FC710D9F87D4.description: Indicates the transportation infrastructure used in the commercialization of forest products in the region studied (e.g. logging roads in Mauricie, Trans-Amazonian Highway, port facilities in British Columbia)

E04CE5FBC3704684A5F0BE6D0A096AE9.description: Indicates types of industries associated with the forest region studied (e.g. paper and saw mills in the Outaouais; saw mills in Manaus, in the Amazon)

5AC18096E35240AFA35A145BDC7861D3.description: Indicates, for the forest region studied, the steps involved in commercializing the resource (e.g. in Mauricie, logging is carried out north of La Tuque, the logs then are transported by truck to the paper mills in Trois-Rivières; after which the manufactured products are shipped to customers by truck, train or ship)

74299CCF2EF8438C953AA0A05A0A6FBD.description: Planning and development of a forest region

4CABAAD36E624377AD4D15B9882136B4.description: Lists activities, other than forest practices, carried out in the forest region studied (e.g. vacationing and recreational tourism in Mauricie, mining in the Amazon)

F139250F66CD492F90754EAC583ABD79.description: Lists wood processing industries associated with the forest region studied (e.g. paper industry, furniture industry, paperboard mills in British Columbia)

70DAE247933D452686117C40718436B8.description: Lists methods used to exploit the forest region studied (e.g. selective cutting, thinning, clearcutting in British Columbia)

45F86037A6C5442E8CEFE4BD372AC4DD.description: Indicates the role of the various stakeholders involved in managing the forest region studied (e.g. the governments who grant cutting rights to logging companies; environmentalists who try to ensure the sustainable development of forests in Abitibi-Témiscamingue)

AF1AAFDDE0214D4CABE68B7C7FE33E44.description: Explains the relationship between characteristics of the climate and the type of forest of the region studied (e.g. the growth of giant trees in British Columbia is mainly due to heavy annual precipitation)

B4D19908AAE64204B028E050A0275E39.description: Describes the types of forests exploited in the region studied (e.g. the boreal forest in AbitibiTémiscamingue consists mainly of black spruce, jack pine and balsam fir; the tropical rainforest in the Amazon contains a wide variety of hardwoods, including precious woods)

69F0930C994247A28190BFD4D8F0FCAF.description: Locates, on a map of the world, the main countries in which forests constitute an important resource (e.g. Brazil, Canada, China, India, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Russia, Sweden)

FF47473DC7354E83AEF39513B19F7BFF.description: Locates, on a map of Québec, the following forest regions: Abitibi-Témiscamingue, Côte-Nord, Outaouais, Saguenay ? Lac-Saint-Jean

322DEF3580BC4528815F4D7BC86FEAAB.description: Locates the forest region studied in the appropriate continent and country

2426A5191CA44F93830F95A00096326C.description: Indicates measures taken to protect a tourist region (e.g. restricting the number of visitors on the dunes in the Îles-de-la-Madeleine; constructing an underground funicular in Savoie)

C1AFBD0801C048B9BD33719BE0E64F91.description: Explains some reactions to tourism development of residents in the region studied (e.g. residents of Lac du Bourget in Savoie oppose boating activities in order to slow down the degradation of the natural environment; Tahitians oppose new developments on coral atolls to preserve these fragile environments)

21F5F592FBE1472CA8B94AD86745BBDA.description: Explains changes brought about by tourism in the region studied (e.g. job creation and infrastructure improvement to meet tourist demand in the Gaspésie; changes in the lifestyle of the Masai in the African Great Lakes region stemming from contact with visitors that may result in a type of acculturation)

71648FA6CE25461DA1ACD43C5067D2DE.description: Indicates behaviours that can contribute to the degradation of a tourist region (e.g. writing graffiti on monuments; using motor vehicles outside authorized trails; dumping oily wastes along a coastline)

BC5DA45651E1432BA70606AED1303896.description: Issue affecting a tourist region or regions

BF1075B04C5B4CD0BBF8BF200D8AC85A.description: Indicates infrastructure that may contribute to the deterioration of natural sites in the tourist region studied (e.g. construction of visitor accommodations along the beaches of the African Great Lakes region; funiculars that provide access to ski resorts in Savoie)

6FF07C739D184A929F54509AFD1B584C.description: Names means used to transport tourists in the tourist region studied (e.g. gondolas or vaporetti in the canals of Venice; photo-safari vans in the African Great Lakes region; sightseeing buses in Île-de-France)

E015B969681940C9B9BAFE00C572B633.description: Indicates the infrastructure in place in the tourist region studied (e.g. campgrounds in the Gaspésie; parking lots on the outskirts of the Lagoon of Venice; national parks in the African Great Lakes region; Disneyland Paris in Île-de-France)

036881C1E989462A90149DCABB71E644.description: Planning and development of a tourist region

BB46DE94A36E4B34A00FE2A8A24C6ABB.description: Establishes the size of the tourist flow in relation to the population of the region studied (e.g. in 2009, the Îles-de-la-Madeleine has four times more tourists than inhabitants; the Lagoon of Venice has seven times more tourists than inhabitants)

CBA4E43AE6BC4EC0AE0F5E14A3CCEE55.description: Explains the relationship between the types of tourism in the region studied and the region’s attractions (e.g. the exotic fauna of the African Great Lakes has given rise to photo safaris, a type of adventure tourism)

8953898B262342DA86DEE14CC82EAC2F.description: Names tourist attractions that reflect the history of the region studied (e.g. the Lido of Venice; the Palace of Versailles in the Île-de-France)

CBBB891B546548F8842F8E18C3B6DCEB.description: Lists natural tourist attractions of the region studied (e.g. the Canadian Shield landscape in the Charlevoix region along the St. Lawrence River; the lagoons of the volcanic islands of Tahiti; the fauna of the African Great Lakes region)

036818B4AD694237ACB64B64F4EF429A.description: Indicates, on a map of the world, the major tourist flow patterns: between Western Europe and the United States, Western Europe and South-East Asia, and the United States and the Caribbean

A2B6D4298EDC40A08173BDDBFC0103DB.description: Locates tourist regions on a map of the world (e.g. Mediterranean coast in Spain, Phuket region in Thailand, the coasts of Florida and the Islands of Hawaii in the United States, the Atlantic coast of Senegal, the Tokyo region in Japan)

E93AD74AB34147099AB58BFD99C43EA6.description: Locates the tourist region studied in the appropriate continent and country

CB7BA288A0C04AA0BBB65AFC891B7D96.description: Indicates limits of heritage protection by UNESCO (e.g. the fact that a city is included on UNESCO’s World Heritage List attracts worldwide attention but does not guarantee that all the necessary measures will be taken to protect the heritage value of the site)

4E214138EA224505BC07495299AF4753.description: Indicates constraints imposed by UNESCO on heritage cities (e.g. obligation to conduct an archaeological investigation prior to building on a site; preserving the historical character of the city when transforming or constructing buildings)

3E1B59FA582A454197B71BE9F9534096.description: Explains disadvantages of having a large influx of tourists in the heritage city studied (e.g. vehicles create congestion in the narrow streets and cause transportation problems for residents in the walled city of Québec)

0D5CC36E873242A78D6D30B1596391FA.description: Lists actions that contribute to the degradation of the heritage site of the city studied (e.g. graffiti on monuments in Paris; stealing stones in Rome or Athens)

64A8A0C2CC6E4DA789A61F2B6DD2C9E4.description: Indicates constraints that the heritage city studied must deal with (e.g. in Québec City, ensuring the peace and tranquility of residents, restoring old buildings in keeping with their style and period)

FFC71C38C8ED425191F69303FFB5834D.description: Indicates actions to take to ensure the protection of heritage cities (e.g. limiting the number of vehicles around the heritage site to protect monuments from pollution; building underground parking lots; providing electric bus service; changing the function of certain buildings)

D6FAB6F83DB04317BD64A546691DA35F.description: Issues affecting a heritage city or cities

B6DB9B465EAD4632805BA9DC29120C2A.description: Indicates measures taken to meet the needs of the residents of the heritage city studied (e.g. creation of parking areas outside the heritage site to limit buses inside the walled city of Québec)

57A9714D75C94E0981AE7A022CB81D2D.description: Indicates infrastructure put in place to facilitate access to the heritage site in the city studied (e.g. parking, pedestrian streets, access roads in Paris; adequate number of tourist information centres to guide visitors in Rome)

FF42A71ED18E42EAA9700C715CC27386.description: Indicates development constraints that the heritage city studied must deal with (e.g. use of small buses in order not to widen the streets inside the walled city of Québec)

D85E339BBB5A471C9CA18A2F60AD6125.description: Planning and development of a heritage city

2C4ACC8F07BD4ED9B5A388DC8F3D0B67.description: Names cities of the world deemed to have heritage character (e.g. Agra, Brasilia, Bruges, Istanbul, Jerusalem, Prague, Timbuktu)

67B23B2124994B189D2FB6CC6FB9748B.description: Names elements recognized for their heritage value in the city studied (e.g. the Ursuline Chapel and the ramparts of the walled city of Québec; the Acropolis in Athens)

496C9380D2C74D298ADA4E971C89BED3.description: Describes the heritage site in the city studied (e.g. in Beijing, the site is not inhabited; it includes three sets of buildings: the Forbidden City and the Temple of the Sky in the centre of the city and the Summer Palace outside the city)

1B53AADC22424C049A0DAC4B4261C022.description: Names organizations that recognize the value of a heritage site in a city (e.g. UNESCO at a global level; Commission des biens culturels in Québec)

CB4F606DDFC64A7D87C0E6E7A9754441.description: Indicates what characterizes the cities that are part of the Organization of World Heritage Cities (OWHC) (e.g. Québec City, Paris and Rome are part of OWHC because the heritage sites are inhabited; Beijing and Athens are not because the heritage sites are not)

D3DCE6475DEC400E804E83BBD6BAB7D8.description: Indicates selection criteria used to recognize world heritage sites (e.g. a site must bear exceptional testimony to an existing or former civilization)

B52C89C8369F4EF69BC2D64FAA8B2999.description: Locates, on a map of the world, heritage cities recognized by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) (e.g. Algiers, Athens, Beijing, Brasilia, Cologne, Istanbul, Havana, Reims, Venice, Zabid)

905F8877534840928BE153EF42F6DDA1.description: Locates the heritage city studied in the appropriate continent and country

60DB0551B6B04656BEF637396D629DCD.description: Explains the relationship between the level of economic development of the country where the city is located and its ability to protect residents from hazards (e.g. cities in developing countries lack resources; few measures are therefore taken to deal with natural disasters, which is less likely to be the case in developed countries)

5B43E4D8DA004E159978256C9DECCBB0.description: Explains the relationship between urbanization and the consequences of natural disasters for city populations (e.g. the more densely populated an area is, the greater the number of people affected by a natural disaster)

910706B2BEC248BEBDF7702C6CACE746.description: Indicates consequences of a natural disaster for the city studied (e.g. in 1989, part of the Bay Bridge collapsed in San Francisco, killing 42 people; the earthquake caused numerous gas leaks and fires in dozens of buildings)

EB917B3A1AD942AE845C4EB97E441798.description: Indicates preventive measures taken to deal with hazards (e.g. designing systems to detect earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, cyclones and tsunamis)

1EB98B8A0DA0421B988EB235DDD188AD.description: Issues affecting a city or cities subject to natural hazards

A9AE0831E87444DC81A30B826A967578.description: Indicates safety measures that the city studied can take to deal with a disaster (e.g. in San Francisco, officials have prepared evacuation plans and planned disaster shelters for displaced residents)

9F23F4CB8AE04998A4B47A440260FFB3.description: Explains the location of neighbourhoods in the city studied in terms of their exposure to natural hazards (e.g. in Quito, the financial district and affluent neighbourhoods are located north of the valley, far from the Pichincha Volcano; low-income neighbourhoods and slums are located on the slopes of the volcano where land is cheaper and the risk of landslides caused by erosion and mudslides or lahars is greater)

F8A1FFA4F784458E9DFF9FF2CF8B585D.description: Indicates means used to protect the residents from natural hazards in the city studied (e.g. earthquake-resistant buildings in San Francisco; stilt houses and dikes to prevent mudslides in Manila)

A4E99827DD8E44F686E4FE5BCC7DA4DC.description: Planning and development of a city subject to natural hazards

1ADD10777A1E4EF4953DD0BC7810A866.description: Establishes the size of the population of the city studied as a proportion of the population of the country (e.g. in 2008, Manila accounts for 14% of the population of the Philippines; San Francisco Bay accounts for 20% of the population of California)

50AD9A3911B7471DB9287A67884C420A.description: Establishes the level of development of the country in which the city studied is located (e.g. San Francisco is located in a developed country)

C4F3A8C3155E46DDA1D31DAF38ABA647.description: Explains why the population is attracted to the city studied despite the instability associated with the hazards (e.g. the fertile volcanic soils of the valley of the Andes attract the population around Quito; the Mediterranean climate and quality of life in California attract people to San Francisco)

8CDA84FD575443318E2067297364D8CB.description: Indicates the relationship between the location of the city studied and the hazard(s) to which it is subject (e.g. San Francisco is built along a series of fault lines, the best known being the San Andreas Fault; Manila is located on an island in a volcanic archipelago and is exposed to several natural hazards: typhoons that cause floods and landslides, volcanic eruptions, earthquakes and tsunamis)

44FA43DE7BC6470093C90C9E505F0BFF.description: Indicates the type(s) of natural hazards to which the city studied is subject (e.g. San Francisco: earthquakes; Quito: eruption of the Pichincha Volcano and earthquakes)

42CBB2946C564E9B86CA7A9C25713BAC.description: Characteristics of a city subject to natural hazards

ED13A803DD434C9DB6357DDF2109DAB2.description: Locates cities subject to natural hazards on a map of the world (e.g. Honolulu, Manila, Naples, Phuket, Port-au-Prince, Quito, San Francisco, Tokyo)

C26C2E7BC30F443EB92ED0854BD642C0.description: Locates the city studied in the appropriate continent and country

4BEB8BD576A4480D8E8CA25AAB95C44C.description: Location of a city subject to natural hazards

843C961FDC8C42318F80F817EB37E6AA.description: Knowledge related to Cities Subject to Natural Hazards

F9F202E880B94473A0D0C3A738753787.description: Explains some effects of population density on the health of residents in metropolises (e.g. high population density increases the risk of the spread of diseases)

5091688072914C17926872285D6463CD.description: Indicates measures taken to reduce problems related to the supply of drinking water in metropolises (e.g. installation of water meters, improved water systems)

01D963CB68544A5F9D3683116F69D811.description: Identifies problems associated with water supply in metropolises (e.g. uneven access to drinking water, depending on the level of development of the countries where metropolises are located)

8FD9D4247C6D4138A7C2AC3108C6A753.description: Indicates measures taken to reduce waste management problems in the metropolis studied (e.g. in New York City, installation of incinerators, development of recycling and waste recovery programs)

6512F84E2475467E877E3B62059BD58A.description: Identifies problems associated with waste management in the metropolis studied (e.g. garbage collection and disposal problems in Cairo; exporting waste to increasingly distant landfill sites in New York City)

508DCB7F6E1148F38102AE86E5B02830.description: Explains some of the repercussions of developing public transit networks in the metropolis studied (e.g. in Sydney, reducing the number of cars on the road cuts down on pollution and improves the quality of life of residents)

B3CCB93088FE47C8ACA1BF7AE953CA04.description: Indicates measures taken to reduce transportation problems in the metropolis studied (e.g. implementation of alternate-day driving restrictions to reduce the number of vehicles on the roads in Mexico City; improved public transit networks in Sydney; implementation of a bicycle rental program in Montréal)

92ECE7BFE2DE4E3C88447534A4CBC215.description: dentifies problems associated with transportation in metropolises (e.g. air pollution, traffic congestion)

F9C505EE5F4E4D258833719FF84983F0.description: Explains some consequences of urban sprawl in the metropolis studied (e.g. as the city of Montréal expands, agricultural land decreases and road congestion increases as suburbanites commute to and from the metropolis)

A30DC94891F64839B19DFFCE422C18EF.description: Indicates measures taken to solve housing problems in the metropolis studied (e.g. construction of satellite cities on the outskirts of Cairo; social housing units in Montréal)

2B14A74E94ED45C3BDD11AA4DF816231.description: Explains why the population of the metropolis studied may be moving to the suburbs (e.g. in Sydney, some residents move to the suburbs in search of more affordable housing, while others seek a better quality of life)

F8AB90C567FD436B99A5717D565C4044.description: Describes housing-related problems in the metropolis studied (e.g. in New York City, housing is scarce, expensive and, in certain cases, unsanitary)

E0237D153FE74C898AEF4FB4FEA69AFB.description: Issues affecting a metropolis or metropolises

1A95C5CE572D437CAEA0540F5DB9948C.description: Indicates development constraints associated with urban sprawl in the metropolis studied (e.g. highway expansion and extension of mass transit lines in Cairo)

79FBC3A243324E359E27C1BF4ED4257E.description: Explains the concentration of transportation networks in the metropolis studied (e.g. because of its large population, New York City has several international airports, an extensive highway system, one of the largest train stations in the world and an international port)

E89E4A68330945228925FEB6BB4C6489.description: Indicates types of infrastructure that stem from particular features of the metropolis studied (e.g. because of its harsh winter conditions, Montréal has developed a network of underground passageways that are connected by metro and link numerous apartment buildings to office buildings and service centres)

ECC3FD5AEC544FE19D038EDB5A99083E.description: Describes the suburbs around the metropolis studied (e.g. the northern and southern suburbs of Montréal include several dozen municipalities, which are primarily residential in nature and have a lower population density than the metropolis)

CD6ED0DF5BF84BAC926210486EC55F54.description: Explains the presence of disadvantaged neighbourhoods or slums in the metropolis studied (e.g. a metropolis attracts people who do not always have the resources necessary for adequate housing and who therefore settle in disadvantaged neighbourhoods in New York City, or in slums in Cairo)

BF92EA5566C64CB3972532DAAC387D9B.description: Describes different neighbourhoods of the metropolis studied (e.g. concentration of high-rise office buildings and convergence of public transit networks in Montréal’s downtown core)

886F86968A5641A39D214E1917D732CD.description: Planning and development of a metropolis

F8F4CCE51F4943949EA189D2A72A7445.description: Explains the concentration of services in the metropolis studied (e.g. the size of the population in the metropolitan area explains why there are several hospitals and universities in Montréal)

8D0481416BB74099A024895E7378B5B9.description: Indicates places where economic and financial power is concentrated in the metropolis studied (e.g. headquarters of large corporations in Sydney)

D7105D0DC47C48A3BBCC1B0266D6948E.description: Indicates places where power is concentrated in the metropolis studied (e.g. The United Nations headquarters is in New York City)

07BE989402E6474CA57DD8769339F789.description: Establishes the relative size of the population of the metropolis studied as a proportion of the country, province, state or district as a whole (e.g. the population of Montréal and its suburbs accounts for approximately 50% of the population of Québec)

505B428F2F7649D194217195DC42F1A3.description: Lists characteristics of the population of the metropolis studied (e.g. large population size and high population density in Mexico City; multiethnicity and urban sprawl in Sydney)

90D2BFF24CF945CF90CD2A6667FC88D4.description: Lists characteristics of the metropolis studied (e.g. high population density, high land occupancy and concentration of services in New York City)

48C7B17DF3BF4A76A8938DA7E601900B.description: Describes site of the metropolis studied (e.g. Montréal is located in the St. Lawrence Plain, on an island surrounded by the St. Lawrence River and the Rivière des Prairies)

3BFE29A30C064CCFBE0B0648B47900B2.description: Locates major metropolises on a map of the world (e.g. Lagos, Cairo, Mexico City, Montréal, Moscow, Mumbai, New York City, Paris, São Paulo, Sydney, Tokyo)

DCFB8AC583E04B22A9F077375E96BD29.description: Locates the metropolis studied in the appropriate continent and country
